questions.question: A 10-year-old has been on strict bedrest for 9 days after a spinal injury. Which complication of immobilization are you most directly trying to prevent with regular active and passive range-of-motion exercises?
options: Increased bone density
Enhanced cardiac output
Contractures and joint stiffness
Improved fine motor coordination

questions.question: A 6-year-old in a long-leg cast after a femur fracture suddenly complains of severe pain in the casted leg. The leg looks pale and feels cool; the child refuses to move the toes. What is the priority action?
options: Notify the provider immediately to assess for compartment syndrome
Elevate the leg on pillows and reassess in 30 minutes
Offer distraction and non-pharmacologic pain measures
Apply a warm pack to improve local circulation

questions.question: A 7-year-old presents with an acutely swollen, painful ankle after a soccer injury. An X-ray shows no fracture. Which initial management is most appropriate?
options: Apply a warm moist compress and encourage early weight bearing
Begin active range-of-motion exercises within 30 minutes of injury
Splint the ankle only if the pain persists beyond 24 hours
Use protection, rest, ice, compression, and elevation of the ankle

questions.question: When comparing fractures in children versus adults, which statement is most accurate?
options: Children’s bones heal more slowly because of their open growth plates
Children have a thicker periosteum, leading to more rapid bone healing
Children’s bones are less vascular, so they are at lower risk for infection
Children rarely experience greenstick fractures due to bone flexibility

questions.question: A 3-year-old in a hip spica cast is being discharged. Which home care teaching is most important to emphasize to the parents?
options: Use talcum powder inside the cast to keep the skin dry
Loosen the cast with a hairdryer on cool if the child is uncomfortable
Protect the cast from urine and stool with careful diapering and check the skin frequently
Remove the cast briefly each day to inspect the underlying skin

questions.question: A child with suspected osteomyelitis of the femur is admitted. Which assessment finding is most consistent with acute osteomyelitis?
options: Painless limb with full range of motion and normal temperature
Generalized pruritus and scleral jaundice
Petechiae over the extremities with mucosal bleeding
Localized bone pain, warmth over the site, fever, and irritability

questions.question: The plan of care for a child with osteomyelitis includes long-term antimicrobial therapy. Which nursing action is most appropriate?
options: Encourage full weight bearing to promote bone healing as soon as pain decreases
Administer IV antibiotics via a PICC line and monitor renal and hepatic function
Switch to oral antibiotics as soon as the child’s pain is controlled
Discontinue antibiotics once the child has been afebrile for 24 hours

questions.question: A 12-year-old with scoliosis has been prescribed a thoracolumbosacral orthosis (TLSO) brace. Which teaching point best promotes treatment effectiveness?
options: Wear the brace as prescribed each day and continue normal school and social activities
Wear the brace only when back pain becomes severe
Remove the brace whenever you are sitting to prevent pressure areas
Expect the brace to permanently cure your scoliosis without further follow-up

questions.question: A 10-year-old is scheduled for spinal fusion with instrumentation for severe scoliosis. In the immediate postoperative period, which assessment is the priority?
options: Oral intake and return of bowel sounds
Pain level and need for additional opioids
Ability to sit unsupported at the bedside
Neurovascular checks of the lower extremities and monitoring respiratory status

questions.question: A child with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is starting on a treatment regimen that includes NSAIDs and possibly methotrexate. What is the primary overall goal of therapy?
options: Cure the disease and prevent any recurrence of joint symptoms
Control pain, preserve joint function, and promote normal growth and development
Restrict activity to minimize fatigue and protect joints from further injury
Avoid medications altogether to prevent long-term adverse effects

questions.question: The nurse teaches parents of a child with JIA about home care. Which statement indicates correct understanding?
options: “We’ll encourage regular exercise, use warm baths, and keep splints on as prescribed.”
“We’ll avoid all heat and use only ice packs when the joints hurt.”
“We’ll stop the medications as soon as she seems better for a few days.”
“We’ll keep her in bed as much as possible to protect her joints.”

questions.question: A 9-month-old infant is being evaluated for possible cerebral palsy. Which finding is most concerning?
options: Startle response with loud noises
Stranger anxiety and crying when separated from parents
Persistent head lag and clenched fists beyond 4 months of age
Ability to sit unsupported and transfer objects hand to hand

questions.question: When explaining cerebral palsy (CP) to parents, which description is most accurate?
options: “It is a progressive muscle disease that will steadily worsen over time.”
“It is a nonprogressive motor disorder caused by a lesion or anomaly in the developing brain.”
“It is an autoimmune disease that causes intermittent episodes of paralysis.”
“It always causes severe intellectual disability that cannot be improved.”

questions.question: A newborn is diagnosed with a myelomeningocele in the lumbosacral area. Before surgical repair, which nursing intervention has the highest priority?
options: Place the infant in a supine position to optimize airway management
Apply a dry dressing to the sac and leave it open to air to promote drying
Begin vigorous passive range-of-motion exercises of the lower extremities
Position the infant prone with hips slightly flexed and cover the sac with moist, sterile dressings

questions.question: The nurse caring for an infant with myelomeningocele includes latex precautions in the plan of care. What is the best rationale?
options: Latex is never used in pediatric care because it always causes skin breakdown
Only infants with a positive skin test for latex allergy require latex precautions
Children with myelomeningocele have a high risk of developing severe latex allergy from repeated early exposure
Latex precautions are necessary only if the child has a family history of atopy or asthma

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy is being evaluated for Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Which finding is most characteristic of DMD?
options: Waddling gait, frequent falls, and using hands to “walk up” the thighs to stand
Spasticity and scissoring of the legs during walking
Intention tremor with ataxic gait and nystagmus
Sudden onset of flaccid paralysis and loss of all reflexes

questions.question: The primary goal of therapy for a child with Duchenne muscular dystrophy is to:
options: Reverse muscle degeneration with high-dose corticosteroids
Prevent all physical activity to protect remaining muscle fibers
Achieve complete cure through early orthopedic surgery
Maintain function in unaffected muscles and keep the child active as long as possible

questions.question: A nurse is planning care for a child with spastic cerebral palsy that affects mobility. Which intervention best supports mobility and function?
options: Encouraging complete bedrest with only passive range of motion
Avoiding orthotics or splints to reduce the risk of pressure injuries
Using physical therapy, assistive devices, and stretching to maximize independence
Withholding activities that require energy expenditure to minimize fatigue

questions.question: A 9-year-old child is newly admitted with a femur fracture and is placed in skeletal traction. Which nursing action is most appropriate?
options: Place the traction weights on the bed when the child complains of pain
Ensure the weights hang freely and maintain proper body alignment
Allow the child to adjust the ropes and pulleys for comfort
Remove the weights briefly during bathing and toileting

questions.question: A nurse is caring for several immobilized children on the unit. Which intervention is most appropriate to prevent venous stasis and venous thromboembolism (VTE)?
options: Apply anti-embolic stockings and encourage active movement of unaffected limbs
Restrict oral fluids to prevent edema and fluid overload
Elevate only the head of the bed to 90 degrees at all times
Massage the calves firmly to improve venous return

questions.question: A 7-year-old in a long-leg cast after a tibia fracture reports increasing pain and tingling in the toes. The toes look pale. Which nursing diagnosis is the priority?
options: Risk for peripheral neurovascular dysfunction related to constrictive cast
Anxiety related to unfamiliar hospital environment
Risk for impaired physical mobility related to musculoskeletal injury
Disturbed sleep pattern related to hospitalization

questions.question: A child with osteomyelitis is being discharged on long-term IV antibiotics via a PICC line at home. Which parent statement indicates effective teaching about a key nursing care priority?
options: “If the bandage gets wet, we can leave it until the next home-care visit.”
“If our child develops fever or redness at the PICC site, we’ll call the provider right away.”
“If she seems better, we can stop the antibiotics a few days early.”
“We will flush the PICC only when it feels blocked.”

questions.question: A 9-year-old in skeletal traction for a femur fracture is at risk for impaired skin integrity. Which intervention best addresses this nursing diagnosis?
options: Encouraging the child to sit upright in bed without changing position
Placing pillows directly under the traction ropes to reduce tension
Providing meticulous skin care and using a pressure-redistribution mattress
Removing the traction weights briefly every 4 hours to change linens

questions.question: A child is post-op day 1 from spinal fusion for scoliosis. Which nursing intervention has highest priority to prevent a serious complication?
options: Encouraging favorite snacks from home to maintain calories
Assisting the child to sit on the edge of the bed with legs dangling
Changing the surgical dressing every 2 hours
Encouraging use of an incentive spirometer and performing frequent respiratory assessments

questions.question: A nurse is planning care for a 5-year-old with spastic cerebral palsy who has difficulty swallowing thin liquids. Which nursing intervention is most appropriate to address the risk for aspiration?
options: Offer large volumes of fluid at each meal to reduce feeding time
Place the child supine during feeds to prevent fatigue
Provide thickened fluids and ensure the child is seated upright with good head control
Limit oral intake and provide most fluids via IV to prevent choking

questions.question: A nurse is caring for a newborn with a lumbosacral myelomeningocele awaiting surgical repair. Which nursing diagnosis is most important in the immediate preoperative period?
options: Risk for deficient fluid volume related to NPO status
Risk for infection related to exposed neural tissue
Risk for delayed growth and development related to chronic condition
Disturbed body image related to visible defect

questions.question: The nurse is providing teaching to parents of a toddler newly diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Which nursing diagnosis should guide early home care teaching?
options: Ineffective breathing pattern related to chest wall deformity
Risk for injury related to progressive muscle weakness and frequent falls
Deficient fluid volume related to decreased oral intake
Risk for constipation related to immobility and opioid use

questions.question: A 13-year-old with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) has morning stiffness that improves throughout the day. Which nursing intervention is most appropriate for this symptom pattern?
options: Instruct the child to avoid all exercise in the morning
Apply cold packs to affected joints immediately on awakening
Encourage warm showers and gentle range-of-motion exercises before school
Schedule complete bedrest until the stiffness resolves

questions.question: A child with cerebral palsy uses ankle–foot orthoses (AFOs) and a walker. The parent asks how to support the child’s mobility at home. Which intervention best reflects the nurse’s understanding of the child’s needs?
options: Encourage the child to crawl instead of walking to conserve energy
Allow the child to walk only at school and use a wheelchair at home
Create safe, uncluttered walking paths and encourage short, frequent periods of ambulation
Remove the AFOs when the child is awake to prevent pressure injuries

questions.question: A 6-year-old in a hip spica cast has had poor appetite and little fluid intake for 2 days. Which nursing diagnosis is the priority?
options: Imbalanced nutrition: less than body requirements related to decreased intake
Risk for impaired skin integrity related to cast and immobility
Risk for ineffective peripheral tissue perfusion related to cast pressure
Deficient knowledge (parental) related to cast care

questions.question: The nurse is planning care for a child with osteomyelitis who reports severe pain at the affected limb despite scheduled analgesics. Which nursing intervention best addresses pain management?
options: Discontinue analgesics and focus on nonpharmacologic measures only
Notify the provider, assess timing of analgesics, and consider multimodal pain strategies
Encourage the child to ignore the pain and focus on schoolwork
Apply ice continuously to the limb for 12 hours without interruption

questions.question: A school-age child is admitted for traction following a femur fracture. Which intervention best addresses the nursing diagnosis Disturbed body image?
options: Limiting visitors until the child adjusts to the traction
Allowing the child to decorate the traction frame and choose clothing that fits over the equipment
Avoiding mirrors so the child does not see the traction apparatus
Telling the child that appearance is not important and will “go back to normal soon”

questions.question: The nurse is planning priority education for parents of a child with myelomeningocele who will require intermittent catheterization at home. Which nursing diagnosis is most relevant?
options: Risk for caregiver role strain related to complex home regimen
Deficient knowledge related to bladder management and infection prevention
Ineffective airway clearance related to neuromuscular weakness
Risk for imbalanced nutrition: more than body requirements

questions.question: A teenager with idiopathic scoliosis is struggling to adhere to wearing a TLSO brace. She states, “I feel ugly in this thing.” Which nursing intervention best addresses her psychosocial needs?
options: Emphasize that she has no choice and must wear the brace
Avoid discussing the brace to minimize embarrassment
Explore her feelings, connect her with peer support, and help plan clothing options that conceal the brace
Tell her that “everyone in high school is self-conscious” and change the subject

questions.question: A child with spastic cerebral palsy has increased muscle tone and scissoring of the legs. Which nursing diagnosis is most appropriate?
options: Risk for infection related to neuromuscular impairment
Ineffective thermoregulation related to muscle spasticity
Impaired physical mobility related to neuromuscular dysfunction
Deficient fluid volume related to increased muscle activity

questions.question: The nurse is caring for a child with Duchenne muscular dystrophy who is becoming increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. Which intervention best addresses a respiratory-focused nursing diagnosis?
options: Encourage the child to sleep flat without pillows to stretch the spine
Cluster physical care so the child spends long periods out of bed
Teach energy conservation, encourage use of cough-assist techniques, and elevate the head of the bed
Restrict the child’s fluid intake to reduce pulmonary congestion

questions.question: A child with JIA is hospitalized for an acute flare. Which nursing intervention best supports the diagnosis Activity intolerance related to joint pain and fatigue?
options: Plan care with alternating rest and activity periods throughout the day
Encourage the child to remain on strict bedrest until pain fully resolves
Schedule all activities together in the morning to “get them over with”
Discourage participation in any physical or play activities while hospitalized

questions.question: A preschooler in a hip spica cast has been less talkative and refuses to participate in play. Which nursing intervention best addresses the nursing diagnosis Risk for delayed growth and development?
options: Limit stimulation and keep the room quiet so the child can rest
Provide age-appropriate play activities that can be done in bed and involve caregivers in play
Focus on physical care only; postpone play until the cast is removed
Encourage the child to watch television most of the day to prevent boredom

questions.question: The nurse suspects developing compartment syndrome in a child with a tight circumferential cast. After notifying the provider, which nursing action is most appropriate while awaiting further orders?
options: Elevate the extremity above the level of the heart to reduce swelling
Apply a heating pad directly over the cast to promote vasodilation
Keep the extremity at heart level, loosen restrictive dressings, and reassess neurovascular status frequently
Encourage the child to bear weight to improve circulation to the limb

questions.question: A child with known latex allergy and myelomeningocele is admitted for surgery. Which nursing intervention best addresses the nursing diagnosis Risk for allergic reaction related to latex exposure?
options: Place a “No dairy products” sign on the door
Use only non-latex equipment and avoid latex-containing toys and gloves in the room
Restrict the child’s visitors to reduce infection risk
Avoid administering any immunizations during this admission
